verses.verse: And many more believed because of His own (Luke 4:32; (John 6:63)) word.

Then they said to the woman, “Now we believe, not because of what you said, for (John 17:8; 1 John 4:14) we ourselves have heard Him and we know that this is indeed the Christ, the Savior of the world.”
(Welcome at Galilee) Now after the two days He departed from there and went to Galilee.
For (Matt. 13:57; Mark 6:4; Luke 4:24) Jesus Himself testified that a prophet has no honor in his own country.
So when He came to Galilee, the Galileans received Him, (John 2:13, 23; 3:2) having seen all the things He did in Jerusalem at the feast; (Deut. 16:16) for they also had gone to the feast.
(A Nobleman’s Son Healed) So Jesus came again to Cana of Galilee (John 2:1, 11) where He had made the water wine. And there was a certain nobleman whose son was sick at Capernaum.
When he heard that Jesus had come out of Judea into Galilee, he went to Him and implored Him to come down and heal his son, for he was at the point of death.
Then Jesus said to him, (John 6:30; Rom. 15:19; 1 Cor. 1:22; 2 Cor. 12:12; (2 Thess. 2:9); Heb. 2:4) “Unless you people see signs and wonders, you will by no means believe.”
The nobleman said to Him, “Sir, come down before my child dies!”
Jesus said to him, “Go your way; your son lives.” So the man believed the word that Jesus spoke to him, and he went his way.
And as he was now going down, his servants met him and told him, saying, “Your son lives!”
Then he inquired of them the hour when he got better. And they said to him, “Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him.”
So the father knew that it was at the same hour in which Jesus said to him, “Your son lives.” And he himself believed, and his whole household.
This again is the second sign Jesus did when He had come out of Judea into Galilee.
(A Man Healed at the Pool of Bethesda) After (Lev. 23:2; Deut. 16:16) this there was a feast of the Jews, and Jesus (John 2:13) went up to Jerusalem.
Now there is in Jerusalem (Neh. 3:1, 32; 12:39) by the Sheep Gate a pool, which is called in Hebrew, Bethesda, having five porches.
In these lay a great multitude of sick people, blind, lame, paralyzed, waiting for the moving of the water.
For an angel went down at a certain time into the pool and stirred up the water; then whoever stepped in first, after the stirring of the water, was made well of whatever disease he had.
Now a certain man was there who had an infirmity thirty-eight years.
When Jesus saw him lying there, and knew that he already had been in that condition a long time, He said to him, “Do you want to be made well?”
The sick man answered Him, “Sir, I have no man to put me into the pool when the water is stirred up; but while I am coming, another steps down before me.”
Jesus said to him, (Matt. 9:6; Mark 2:11; Luke 5:24) “Rise, take up your bed and walk.”
And immediately the man was made well, took up his bed, and walked. And (John 9:14) that day was the Sabbath.
The Jews therefore said to him who was cured, “It is the Sabbath; (Ex. 20:10; Neh. 13:19; Jer. 17:21, 22; Matt. 12:2; Mark 2:24; Luke 6:2) it is not lawful for you to carry your bed.”
He answered them, “He who made me well said to me, ‘Take up your bed and walk.’ ”
Then they asked him, “Who is the Man who said to you, ‘Take up your bed and walk’ ?”
But the one who was (Luke 13:14; 22:51) healed did not know who it was, for Jesus had withdrawn, a multitude being in that place.
Afterward Jesus found him in the temple, and said to him, “See, you have been made well. (Matt. 12:45; (Mark 2:5); John 8:11) Sin no more, lest a worse thing come upon you.”
The man departed and told the Jews that it was Jesus who had made him well.
(Honor the Father and the Son) For this reason the Jews (Luke 4:29; John 8:37; 10:39) persecuted Jesus, and sought to kill Him, because He had done these things on the Sabbath.
But Jesus answered them, ((John 9:4; 17:4)) “My Father has been working until now, and I have been working.”
Therefore the Jews (John 7:1, 19) sought all the more to kill Him, because He not only broke the Sabbath, but also said that God was His Father, (John 10:30; Phil. 2:6) making Himself equal with God.

Then Jesus answered and said to them, “Most assuredly, I say to you, (Matt. 26:39; John 5:30; 6:38; 8:28; 12:49; 14:10) the Son can do nothing of Himself, but what He sees the Father do; for whatever He does, the Son also does in like manner.
For (Matt. 3:17; John 3:35; 2 Pet. 1:17) the Father loves the Son, and ((Matt. 11:27)) shows Him all things that He Himself does; and He will show Him greater works than these, that you may marvel.
For as the Father raises the dead and gives life to them, (Luke 7:14; 8:54; (John 11:25)) even so the Son gives life to whom He will.
For the Father judges no one, but (Matt. 11:27; 28:18; (John 3:35; 17:2; Acts 17:31; 1 Pet. 4:5)) has committed all judgment to the Son,
that all should honor the Son just as they honor the Father. (Luke 10:16; 1 John 2:23) He who does not honor the Son does not honor the Father who sent Him.

(Life and Judgment Are Through the Son) “Most assuredly, I say to you, (John 3:16, 18; 6:47) he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, ((1 John 3:14)) but has passed from death into life.
Most assuredly, I say to you, the hour is coming, and now is, when ((Eph. 2:1, 5; Col. 2:13)) the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear will live.
For (Ps. 36:9) as the Father has life in Himself, so He has granted the Son to have ((John 1:4; 14:6); 1 Cor. 15:45) life in Himself,
and (John 9:39; (Acts 10:42; 17:31)) has given Him authority to execute judgment also, (Dan. 7:13) because He is the Son of Man.
Do not marvel at this; for the hour is coming in which all who are in the graves will ((1 Thess. 4:15-17)) hear His voice

(Is. 26:19; (1 Cor. 15:52)) and come forth— (Dan. 12:2; Matt. 25:46; Acts 24:15) those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation.
(John 5:19) I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because (Matt. 26:39; John 4:34; 6:38) I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.
(The Fourfold Witness) (John 8:14; Rev. 3:14) “If I bear witness of Myself, My witness is not true.
((Matt. 3:17; John 8:18; 1 John 5:6)) There is another who bears witness of Me, and I know that the witness which He witnesses of Me is true.
You have sent to John, ((John 1:15, 19, 27, 32)) and he has borne witness to the truth.
